terms.term: Describe 7 characteristics of a Cognitive Learner
terms.definition:
- makes many mistakes
- uses trial and error
-can’t use intrinsic feedback 
-movements lack fluency, rhythm and are jerky
-needs conscious thought
-relies on extrinsic feedback 
-creates mental picture through demonstration or rehearsal

terms.term: Describe 6 characteristics of the Associative stage:
terms.definition:
-less mistakes made
-can use KR and KP
-matches performance to mental model
-motor programmes begin to form
-movements become more fluent, less jerky, smoother
-uses intrinsic (kinaesthetic) feedback + extrinsic

terms.term: Describe the 6 characteristics of the autonomous stage
terms.definition:
-Skills are automatic, fluent, consistent, well-grooved, accurate
-motor programmes are fully formed
-requires little conscious thought
-spare attentional capacity to focus on strategic play, adapt and refine.
-performance habitual ad overlearned
-effectively use intrinsic feedback to self-correct

-little decision-making
-little conscious thought to perform
-little sub-routines
-can be taught whole skill in a repetitive manner

-involves lots of decisions making
-more information processing
-many subroutines
-must be broken down to teach skill (hard to learn)

Affected by environment
Externally paced
Perceptual skills need to be adjusted to match situation

Not affected by environment
Self paced
Habitual movement s
Stable and predictable

Performer controls the rate of activity 
Performer decides when to start 
Tend to be closed skills
Performer = proactive

Rate of activity controlled by external factors
Performer reacts to a stimulus 
Tend to be open skills

Large muscle group 
Large movement
Not accurate/. Precise
Fundamental skills

Small movements
Small muscle groups
Intricate and precise
Coordination

Well defined beginning and end 
Bride in nature 
Hard to break down as single skill

Number of discrete skills put together in a sequence
Order of elements important
First movement triggers next one

No obvious beginning and end
Activity is ongoing - skill repeated as a set pattern
End of one movement is beginning of next

Skills have elements
Difficult to separate elements

Skill can be split up into sub routines
Elements are easily identified as separate movements.

-part
-whole
-whole part whole
-progressive part

-massed
-distributed
-fixed
-varied

Breaking down a movement into individual subroutines 
+)doesn’t overload performer with info
-) reduces kinaesthetic awareness
+) useful for beginners and complex skills

Skill is learned in its entirety 
+) useful for simple continuous skills
-) hard to learn complex skills this way
+) promotes kinaesthetic awareness

Practicing skill in its entirety and then breaking the skill down into its sub routines, before completing the skill as a whole again.
+) enable some kinaesthetic feel.
+) useful for complex skills which can be clearly separated into individual sub routines.
-) less kinaesthetic feel the longer spent using this method.
-) time consuming

Learning the individual sub routines in chronological order and then joining these together in order. Eventually the skill is learned in its entirety.
+) Aids correct time of each sub routine.
+) enables understanding of how the sub routines interact
-) disjointed feel to the skill
-) can make the skill flow less effectively

Continuous practice of simple skills without breaks.
+) useful for those with high fitness and motivation levels
-) can become repetitive and tedious
-) should not be used during dangerous skills

Practice is interrupted with breaks for discussion and recovery
+) useful for those with low fitness and motivation
+) useful for complex skills which would benefit from discussion
-) can be time-consuming
+) allows for recovery between reps so performance can be substantiated
-) not for discrete skills

Continuous practice of a specific skill
-) does not take into account any changes in the performers, environment or situation
+) enables a good level of skill rehearsal
+) useful for closed skills
-) can be tedious
-) may not improve skills when performed in an open environment

Practising a skill in different situations
+) environmental situation can be changed by the coach, preparing the performer for various match conditions
+) useful for open skills and games players specifically
-) time-consuming
+) improve selective attention
-) often require requires learning using a fixed method first so not fully comprehensive

When knowledge of how to do one skill helps us learn a new skill.
Eg. Knowing how to do a serving tennis helps us learn how to smash in badminton e.g.golf swing – batting in cricket, drive in cricket – pass in hockey.
E.g. Javelin throw – spike in volleyball ( over arm )

When knowing how to do one skill hinders the learning of a new skill
Eg. Cricket bowl – shotput throw (straight arm)
Eg. Shot in basketball – netball shot ( overdo it – must stay where you are)
Eg. Receiving pass in netball – receiving pass in basketball ( standstill )
Eg. Forehand in squash – four hand tennis ( loose wrist.)
Eg. Rowing arm action – breaststroke arm action (sweeping pull.)

Knowing how to do a skill with one limb and transferring knowledge to be able to do the same School with the other limb
Eg. Football pass right foot and left foot.
E.g. tennis for hand right and left arm 
E.g. catching right and left hand

A skill that is learnt now has an influence on a skill that was learnt in the past
E.g. Javelin past – spike volleyball now – > positive influence on throwing action in javelin
E.g. tennis serve – badminton smash now –> positive influence on tennis serve

The knowledge of a skill learnt in the past influences the learning of a new skill now.
Eg. Learning a tennis serve in the past helps you learn a badminton smash now.

terms.term: What are 5 ways to optimise positive transfer
terms.definition:
-highlight similarities: connect both skills to enhance understanding 
-overlearn skills: thorough mastery of skill 1 ensures better transfer
-realistic practice: activities mimic real life scenarios
-progressive learning: skills are taught in stages to avoid confusion 
-provides positive feedback: reinforces correct performance and transfer
Description/explanation often used alongside visual guidance for cognitive learner/beginners. On its own for autonomous performers (eg. Tactics)

- increases understanding (helps gauging clear idea of what needs to be done)
- holds attention
- improves motivation (through q+a or engagement)

-loses motivation if talk for too long/waffle 
-some skills can’t just be explained to be fully understood 
-risk of information overload 
-interpretation error risk
Demonstration to provide performer with clear mental image

- allows mental image to form of
- encourages observational learning 
- beneficial for beginners to understand new concepts better
-versatile / easy for coach eg. Video, in person demo etc
- skill can be easily shown in different stages eg. Isolation to game situation

- potential info overload so must highlight important aspects of performance 
-demonstration may be incorrect
-Coach may be incapable of demonstrating skill
-Demonstration might be too quick to get a proper understanding
Physical support - physically manoeuvering the performers, body with your hands
Equipment support - physical support through harnesses

Reduces danger and fear/increased safety
Gain kinaesthetic feel for the movement in a safe way 
Increases confidence in performance, especially if cognitive learner 
Supports part practice methods

terms.term: Negatives of mechanical and manual guidance
terms.definition:
Become too dependent on it
False kinaesthesis risk 
Reduction in learners control
Information about successes of the performance. Can be intrinsic or extrinsic for example, nice shot.

Strengthens stimulus response bond
Reinforces skill learning 
Improves motivation 
Builds confidence in cognitive stage

Potentially Reinforces wrong aspect of performance
Not always helpful if not specific 
Doesn’t tell you how to improve /what to do next
Information about the unsuccessful parts of the performance. Can be intrinsic or extrinsic. For example, your turns were sloppy.

Can be motivational for some performers who need criticism to improve
Highlights areas of improvement 
Suited to auto learners who can handle criticism and require it to improve as most things are already done well 
Allows for refinement and fine detail 
Prevent prevents dry reduction as it keeps setting new goals for performer

Can be Demotivational
Reduces confidence 
Doesn’t tell them the full picture as excludes what they did correctly
Information about the quality of the performance and the technique

Allows for a kinaesthetic sense
When against strong opposition allows to focus on positives whilst losing and take something useful from the loss 
Focuses on performance over outcome which means the performers in control 
Stimulates areas of improvement 
Essential for school learning and transitioning into autonomous stage 
Improves motivation 
Good for closed skills 
Increase his confidence in ability to perform a skill

Useless if inaccurate 
Doesn’t consider outcome so not as useful for outcome goals achievement 
Can cause overload
Information about the outcome of the performance (terminal)

Useful for beginners (did the ball go in the hoop)
Useful for experts (outcome goal achievements)
Motivational (if results are positive)
Satisfaction ((I can tell im getting better because im winning more) 
Measurable / objective

Demotivational if results aren’t positive 
Lacks technical; detail so hard to improve based on it 
Unrepresentative eg. If performer played well but lost
Information from within the performer about pro perceptions and kinaesthesia

Always available
Not relying on a coach suitable for autonomous learners who rely on it to self evaluate 
Allows for self correction

Cognitive learners don’t have enough experience to use it
Might be inaccurate 
Depend depends on schema being broad enough
Information from others or external sources, such as a coach or the crowd or parents or teammates

Gives a different interpretation which performer couldn’t see
Coach may be experienced 
Important for beginners who can’t self correct yet

Harder to do concurrently
Doesn’t provide kinaesthesis 
Not always available 
Often team based /not specific to individual performer
Learning through reinforcement and punishment

terms.term: Define and describe stimulus response bond
terms.definition: The connection between stimulus and the response that stimulus. A specific stimulus results in a specific response. It is an associationist or a connectionist theory for example seeing a netball flying at you you catch it or hearing a buzzer and diving in Swimming.
The process of learning how to do something by trying different methods and learning from mistakes

How the coach controls the environment for example setting up practices or drills to promote learning a new skill eg using cones to promote efficient football dribbling skills, using weighted ropes to add resistance in Swimming, using a noodle for a backstroke star or a beach ball

terms.term: Describe shaping behaviour of the performer
terms.definition: Behaviour is modified in order to carry out the desired outcome/correct movement
Actions which strengthen the stimulus response bond and increase the likelihood of behaviour/the desired response occurring. Can be both positive and negative.

Satisfies are provided to the learner when they decide response occurs which strengthens the stimulus response bond and increases the likelihood of behaviour recurring. E.g. cheering when you make 15 m off the wall.
The removal of criticism when the desired response occurs which strengthens the stimulus response bond eg. Shouting at you continuously and then stopping shouting at you when you do 15 m underwater.

An unpleasant consequence in order to avoid an undecided response recurring by weakening the stimulus response bond eg. When the swimmer touches on their front at the end of a back straight length they are made to do 50 press ups to prevent them finishing illegally in the future.

terms.term: What are the five principles of operant conditioning?
terms.definition:
Stimulus response bond
Trial and error learning 
Manipulating the environment 
Shaping behaviour 
Punishment and reinforcement
Learning by observing others and imitating behaviour

terms.term: What are the four stages involved in observational learning?
terms.definition:
Attention
Retention 
Motor production 
Motivation
The extent to which the performer notices the information. This is done through a demonstration.

Done by somebody of high status eg coach or teacher
Person demonstrating as a role model 
Demonstration should be accurate and successful 
Demonstration should be of high-quality 
Demonstrator should be attractive 
Learners must be physically and mentally ready to complete the school demonstrated
The extent to which behaviour is remembered. This is saved in the mind via a visual image. This is ingrained in a long-term memory through mental rehearsal.

terms.term: What is meant by motor production?
terms.definition: Is the performer physically able to do the movement this refers to the learning of being physically and mentally mature and able?
The desire to achieve the goal and learn. This occurs through intrinsic motivation like pride, extrinsic motivation like external rewards medals trophies, general praise, specific praise.

terms.term: What are the aspects of the cognitive learning theory?
terms.definition:
Gestaltist approach
Problem-solving /insight learning
Thinking and understanding 
Whole learning (completed in its entirety)
Previous experience /long-term memory
Intervening variables (everything that the learner must take into account to solve a problem)

terms.term: Analyse how following the cognitive theory of learning may affect their learning
terms.definition: Following the content of the learning means to perform actively thinks about and understands what they’re doing. This can help the learner develop a better understanding of the skill aligning to apply it more effectively in game situations. Because they’re learning the school is a whole they can also develop their kinaesthetic awareness and learn to self correct without relying entirely on the coach. However, if the school is complex complex or dangerous, the performer may find it too difficult to understand and could lose motivation if they don’t make progress quickly.

terms.term: Describe Craik and Lockharts level of processing model
terms.definition:
How deeply we consider information determines how long the memory lasts.
First level = structural which involves paying attention to what the info looks like (visually)
2nd level: phonetic/acoustic which refers to how the information sounds.
These are shallow because they don’t involve much processing 
These will result in a weaker memory trace as shallow processing means info is less likely to be stored in LTM
3rd level is semantic which considers the meaning of the information
This is deep because it involves more processing
This is more likely to result in a stronger memory trace as it involves deepened processing which is more likely to be stored in LTM
Information is more likely to be remembered if it has meaning / personal relevance.

terms.term: Describe the sensory register/short term sensory stores in Atkinson and shiffrins multistore memory model
terms.definition:
Info enters via the senses 
Capacity = limitless 
Duration = up to 1 seconds 
Selective attention takes place here 
Information is filtered to the short term memory (encoding)
The filtering in of relevant information and filtering out of irrelevant cues. Relevant info is sent to the STM.

terms.term: Give an sporting example of selective attention
terms.definition: In tennis selective attention takes place when the opposition returns a serve. Relevant info such as the ball speed and trajectory is filtered into the STM whereas irrelevant info like position of line judges, noise of the crowd etc is filtered out/discarded becasue it is useless when completing the return shot.

terms.term: Describe the STM (working memory) is the MSMM
terms.definition:
Receives relevant info from sensory register 
Capacity: 5-9 items 
Chunking can increase capacity / easier to retain info 
Duration: 30seconds
Info is passed to LTM (encoding)
Grouping together different pieces of info to make one piece of information so more items can be remembered more easily. Eg. Line out routines in rugby

terms.term: Describe the LTM is the MSMM
terms.definition:
Stores motor programmes 
Receives info from stm (encoded)
Capacity = limitless 
Duration = permanent 
Info is passed back to the stm (decoding) through retrieval.

+ simple to understand 
+) explains how skills which have been rehearsed can be remembered / retrieves ebtter from LTM 
+) ex[plains how ppl with brain damage can suffer from dysfunctional memory 
+ LTM explains how an individual can perform a skill which they havent done for a long time 

- doesnt explain why individuals may remember one type og info eg. Diagram but not another eg. Coaches explanation 
- doesnt account for individual differences eg. In capacity or duration 
- doesnt account for depth of processing eg. Interests/motivation/ meaning of info / personal relevance 
- doesnt explain how some things which are repeated /rehearsed are forgotten

terms.term: Using a+s’s MSMM, suggest how a performer learns a new skill so that it becomes stored in their LTM
terms.definition: Info passes from environment into sensory register with limitless capacity and a duration of up to 1 sec. Here, selective attention takes place where irrelevant info is discarded and relevant info is filtered into the stm. STM holds 7+-2 items for up to 30 secs. Decisions made in stm as incoming info is interpreted. Rehearsal aids retention so it is stored in LTM. Chunking helps increase storage/capacity. Info becomes encoded. Skill is stored as motor programmes in LTM. Info is retrieved to stm and updated back in LTM to aid LTM storage.

terms.term: Suggests some methods that a coach could use to help info be stored in the LTM
terms.definition: Chunking, avoid overload, association/transfer, make info relevant to performer, rehearsal/repetition.

terms.term: Analyse how the stm and LTM are used in the performance of physical activities
terms.definition:
STM: 
Perception occurs / decision making, 
This is where info is judged (cricket batter judging spin of ball)
Info is rehearsed (eg. Flight of ball remembered)
Info is organised in brain (eg flight vs speed of ball) 

LTM:
Motor programmes formed eg. Tennis player stored no. Of serve-return movement patterns 
Current and past experiences compared eg. Previous successful returns remembered 
Info retrieved to STM

title: Skill Acquisition Feedback Guidance Transfer Memory Models Learning theories
